riddle: It is greater than God and more evil than the devil. The poor have it, the rich need it and if you eat it you will die. What is it?
It walks on four legs in the morning, two legs at noon and three legs in the evening. What is it?
What always runs but never walks, often murmurs, never talks, has a bed but never sleeps, has a mouth but never eats?
At night they come without being fetched. By day they are lost without being stolen. What are they?
The one who makes it, sells it. The one who buys it, never uses it. The one that uses it never knows that he is using it. What is it?
The more you have of it, the less you see. What is it?
What has a head, a tail, is brown, and has no legs?
What is black when you get it, red when you use it, and white when you're all through with it?

I am always hungry,
I must always be fed,
The finger I touch,
Will soon turn red
I know a word of letters three. Add two, and fewer there will be!

All about, but cannot be seen,
Can be captured, cannot be held,
No throat, but can be heard.

Until I am measured I am not known,
Yet how you miss me when I have flown.

I drive men mad
For love of me,
Easily beaten,
Never free.

My life can be measured in hours,
I serve by being devoured.
Thin, I am quick
Fat, I am slow
Wind is my foe.

Glittering points that downward thrust,
Sparkling spears that never rust.

You heard me before, yet you hear me again,
Then I die, until you call me again.

Three lives have I.
Gentle enough to soothe the skin,
Light enough to caress the sky,
Hard enough to crack rocks.

What does man love more than life
Fear more than death or mortal strife
What the poor have, the rich require,
and what contented men desire,
What the miser spends and the spendthrift saves
And all men carry to their graves?

I build up castles.
I tear down mountains.
I make some men blind,
I help others to see.
What am I?
It cannot be seen, it weighs nothing, but when put into a barrel, it makes it lighter. What is it?
Say my name and I disappear. What am I?
A box without hinges, lock or key, yet golden treasure lies within. What is it?

I can be long, or I can be short.
I can be grown, and I can be bought.
I can be painted, or left bare.
I can be round, or square.
What am I?
I am a box that holds keys without locks, yet they can unlock your soul. What am I?
My first is twice in apple but not once in tart. My second is in liver but not in heart. My third is in giant and also in ghost. Whole I am best when I am roast. What am I?

When you went into the woods you got me.
You hated me yet you wanted to find me.
You went home with me cause you could not find me
What was it?

A mile from end to end, yet as close to as a friend. A precious commodity, freely given. Seen on the dead and on the living. Found on the rich, poor, short and tall, but shared among children most of all. What is it?
I am full of holes, yet I am full of water. What am I?
Feed me and I live, give me drink and I die. What am I?
What makes a loud noise when changing its jacket, becomes larger but weighs less?
The more you take, the more you leave behind.

Alive without breath,
As cold as death,
Clad in mail never clinking,
Never thirsty, ever drinking

Until I am measured
I am not known,
Yet how you miss me
When I have flown.

The cost of making only the maker knows,
Valueless if bought, but sometimes traded.
A poor man may give one as easily as a king.
When one is broken pain and deceit are assured.

Who makes it, has no need of it.
Who buys it, has no use for it.
Who uses it can neither see nor feel it.

I build up castles. I tear down mountains.
I make some men blind,
I help others to see.
What am I?

Glittering points that downward thrust,
Sparkling spears that never rust.

Die without me, Never thank me.
Walk right through me, never feel me.
Always watching, never speaking.
Always lurking, never seen.

I go around in circles,
But always straight ahead
Never complain,
No matter where I am led.

Voiceless it cries,
Wingless flutters,
Toothless bites,
Mouthless mutters.

If a man carried my burden
He would break his back.
I am not rich,
But leave silver in my track.

Weight in my belly,
Trees on my back,
Nails in my ribs,
Feet I do lack.

A thousand colored folds stretch toward the sky,
Atop a tender strand,
Rising from the land,
Until killed by maiden's hand,
Perhaps a token of love, perhaps to say goodbye.
Hands she has but does not hold, teeth she has but does not bite, feet she has but they are cold, eyes she has but without sight. Who is she?

Bright as diamonds,
Loud as thunder,
Never still,
A thing of wonder.

Inside me the adventurous find
Quests and treasures of every kind.
Trolls, goblins, orcs, and more, await
Within my closed walls for
All those that wish to visit me.
Your hands are the key
To secrets untold,
And your mind will unlock the door.
What am I?

Two bodies have I,
though both joined in one.
The more still I stand,
the quicker I run.
What am I?

As a whole, I am both safe and secure.
Behead me, and I become a place of meeting.
Behead me again, and I am the partner of ready.
Restore me, and I become the domain of beasts.
What am I?
Walk on the living, they don't even mumble. Walk on the dead, they mutter and grumble

What is greater than God,
More evil than the Devil,
The poor have it,
The rich want it,
but if you eat me,
you will die?
What has four wheels and flies?

I do not breathe, but I run and jump.
I do not eat, but I swim and stretch.
I do not drink, but I sleep and stand.
I do not think, but I grow and play.
I do not see, but you see me every day.

People are hired to get rid of me.
I am often hiding under your bed.
In time I will always return you see.
Bite me and you are surely dead.

Large as a mountain, small as a pea,
Endlessly swimming in a waterless sea.

What has a forest but no trees.
cities but no people and
rivers but no water??
Runs smoother than any rhyme, loves to fall but cannot climb!
What do you use to hoe a row, slay a foe, and wring with woe?

At night they come without being fetched,
And by day they are lost without being stolen.
As light as a feather, but you can't hold it for ten minutes.
My face is always changing, but is always the same.

A precious stone, as clear as diamond.
Seek it out whilst the sun is near the horizon.
Though you can walk on water with its power,
Try to keep it, and it will vanish ere an hour.

Take me and scratch my head.
What once was red,
Is black instead.
What am I?

I weaken all men for hours each day.
I show you strange visions while you are away.
I take you by night, by day take you back,
None suffer to have me, but do from my lack.
What am I?

It has a long neck,
A name of a bird,
Feeds on cargo of ships,
It is not alive.
What is put on a table, cut, but never eaten?

What runs around a city
but never moves?

My thunder comes before my lightning.
My lightning comes before my rain.
And my rain dries all the ground it touches.
What am I?
